title: 114_s3538
content: The "Prevent Trafficking in Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property as outlined in international conventions and establishes a policy to prevent illicit import, export, and transfer of ownership of cultural property. The United States policy aims to enhance efforts to interdict, detain, seize, and investigate illegally imported cultural property, disrupt smuggling networks, and support prosecution of individuals involved in illegal trade in cultural property. Additionally, it seeks to protect cultural property in line with international obligations. The United States aims to enhance efforts to interdict, detain, seize, and investigate illegally imported cultural property, disrupt smuggling networks, and support prosecution of individuals involved in illegal trade. It also seeks to protect cultural property in accordance with international obligations. The Department of Homeland Security is tasked with various activities related to enhancing efforts to interdict, detain, seize, and investigate illegally imported cultural property, disrupt smuggling networks, and support prosecution of individuals involved in illegal trade. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement are required to designate coordinators to manage policies and procedures for illegally imported cultural property. They must update existing directives and create new ones if necessary. The updated directives aim to reflect changes in cultural property law, investigate and support prosecutions of those involved in illegal importation of cultural property, and enhance communication and coordination efforts. The directives aim to enhance communication and coordination between relevant offices of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in investigating illegal importation of cultural property, and ensure personnel receive training in relevant cultural property laws, identification of at-risk cultural property, and investigative techniques related to illegal trade. The directives aim to enhance communication and coordination between relevant offices of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in investigating illegal importation of cultural property, ensuring personnel receive training in relevant laws, identification of at-risk cultural property, and investigative techniques related to illegal trade. The Secretary of Homeland Security will ensure that DHS components can partner with the Smithsonian Institution to utilize their personnel for cultural property protection activities. A report will be required. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and the Commissioner of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement must submit a report to congressional committees on the progress of implementing the Act and efforts to combat illegal importation of cultural property.
